content.definition: Severe ischemic pain occurring in the foot at rest, typically affecting the distal foot and toes, worse with elevation and at night, and relieved by dependency. Rest pain represents Fontaine Stage III or Rutherford Category 4 peripheral arterial disease and is a defining feature of chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI).

mechanism: Severe reduction in arterial perfusion pressure to foot
Inadequate blood flow to meet resting metabolic demands
nocturnal_worsening: Loss of gravity-assisted perfusion when supine
Reduced sympathetic tone (vasodilation proximal, inadequate distally)
dependency_relief: Gravity augments perfusion pressure to foot
Increased venous pressure maintains capillary flow

character: Severe, often described as worst pain ever
temporal_pattern: Worse at night (awakens patient from sleep)
Relieved by hanging foot over bed edge (dependency)
associated_findings: May have tissue loss (ulcer or gangrene)

definitive: Goal: restore pulsatile flow to foot

prognosis.without_treatment: High risk of limb loss within 1 year

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical features of ischemic rest pain
Understand pathophysiology of nocturnal worsening and dependency relief
Know hemodynamic criteria defining rest pain
clinical_pearls: Rest pain is WORSE at night, RELIEVED by dependency (opposite of venous)
Patient hangs foot over bed edge to sleep = classic history
Ankle pressure <50 mmHg or toe pressure <30 mmHg
Rest pain = CLTI = urgent revascularization needed
Without treatment: high limb loss rate within 1 year
